(CBS) QUOTE OF THE DAY
“Yesterday I was a dog. Today I'm a dog. Tomorrow I'll probably 
      still be a dog. Sigh! There's so little hope for advancement.” - 
      Charles M. Schulz 



TODAY’S TRIVIA A capon is a castrated rooster. 
      



TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWS Here's an early look 
      at what we are working on for tonight's broadcast of the CBS EVENING NEWS 
      from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric... Hi everyone, 
      A legendary figure of the religious right has passed away. The 
      Rev. Jerry Falwell died this afternoon. The cause of death wasn’t 
      immediately disclosed but he’s had a history of heart trouble. In his 
      life, he was seen as a visionary to some conservatives and an archenemy to 
      liberals. Falwell leaves a legacy of founding the Moral Majority, 
      bolstering the evangelical community and sculpting it into a major 
      political force. Our Richard Schlesinger will tell the story of 
      this influential man’s life. We’ll also have a slate of in-depth 
      interviews with religious leaders, academics and public figures about Rev. 
      Falwell’s impact on religion and politics in America. In other 
      news, the search continues for information about three U.S. soldiers 
      feared captured by an al Qaeda group during a weekend ambush in Iraq. 
      Troops have detained 11 people and questioned hundreds in connection with 
      the attack. Sharyn Alfonsi is at Fort Drum, New York, where the 
      troops killed and kidnapped last weekend were based. One of the 
      savviest ways companies are reaching kids is through the Internet. But 
      forget old-fashioned pop-up ads. What’s targeting your children is fun for 
      them and highly profitable for the advertisers – it’s called 
      “advergaming,” and John Blackstone will report on the phenomenon 
      for tonight’s installment of “Gotta Have It: The Hard Sell To 
      Kids.” Please join us tonight for 
      these stories and more. Katie For more on two of the 
      stories noted above, please click on the following links...

Rev. Jerry Falwell Dead At 73 Click Here Gas Hits Record 
      Prices; Will It Go Higher? Click Here Here's an early look 
      at one of the stories we are working on for Wednesday's broadcast of the 
      CBS EVENING NEWS... Cell phone companies are now targeting TWEENS .. 
      selling them those special phone features that fatten up the bill. Part of 
      our series -- GOTTA HAVE IT, The Hard Sell to Kids. That, and much more, 
      Wednesday night on the CBS Evening News. If you would like more 
      information on the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com TONIGHT ON 
      DAVID LETTERMAN Comedian Don Rickles joins Dave tonight along with 
      actor Michael Imperioli… Also, don’t miss a Top Ten List presented by 
      actor Masi Okawill. Plus, musical guests Wilco! 



WEDNESDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY 
      SHOW Harry Smith, Julie Chen and Russ 
      Mitchell anchor THE EARLY SHOW from 
      New York. Dave Price will bring us the weather. Hannah Storm 
      is off. Along with the top news of the day, we will also have 
      the following stories: FAREWELL TO BOB BARKER: Tuesday 
      night on CBS, Bob Barker is hosting a special high stakes money 
      game...The Price is Right One Million Dollar Spectacular. After 
      thirty-five years, the legendary game show host is preparing to step down 
      and enjoy his golden years. EARLY SHOW 
      National Correspondent Hattie Kauffman will have more on his long 
      and stellar career. JUST ASK A WOMAN. . . ABOUT WORK: It 
      comes as no surprise that women ask a lot of questions. So this week we 
      decided to try and answer those questions in a new series Just Ask A 
      Woman. Wednesday morning, we’ll take a look at generations in the 
      workplace. This month alone millions of more women are joining the 
      workforce. And age differences can make for a challenging office 
      environment. Pretty soon one of those younger women could be your boss. 
      Are you ready? And can it really work? We visited one woman in Chicago who 
      is giving a whole new meaning to what it means to be a young boss. Our new 
      EARLY SHOW Contributor Mary Lou 
      Quinlan will join us with more. SHREK THE THIRD 
      PRINCESSES: Shrek The Third reunites all your favorite 
      characters from the first two films with some very funny additions. When 
      there is a coup in the kingdom of Far, Far, Away, Shrek's wife Fiona is 
      joined by some familiar princesses to help save the Kingdom. Cameron Diaz 
      returns as Fiona, Cheri Oteri plays Sleeping Beauty, and Amy Sedaris plays 
      Cinderella. Wednesday morning, we’ll ask the three lovely ladies - Cameron 
      Diaz, Cheri Oteri and Amy Sedaris – what it was like working on the film. 
      CHIC ON A SHOESTRING: With temperatures rising, dressing 
      comfortably for work is of the utmost importance. So how can you achieve 
      casual, effortless style without losing the spirit of summer? Cheryl 
      Kramer of Redbook magazine will join us with some warm weather 
      options perfectly appropriate for a day at the office. SUPREME 
      DISCOMFORT: CLARENCE THOMAS: Clarence Thomas has long been a 
      controversial figure and one who, says author Kevin Merida, is a 
      conflicted man. Is Thomas an affirmative action success story? Or an 
      example of forgotten roots? Thomas has opposed affirmative action and 
      shied away from the liberal agenda. Now, a new profile of the Justice, 
      Supreme Discomfort: The Divided Soul of Clarence Thomas, examines 
      the fascinating figure. Wednesday morning, author Kevin Merida will join 
      us to discuss the man behind the book. WOMEN AND EXERCISE: 
      How much exercise is enough to improve your health? It turns out, just 
      fifteen minutes a day could be all you need to stay healthy. We’ll have 
      the information you need to know before your next workout. 
      JERRY BRUCKHEIMER ON PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: AT WORLD’S 
      END: In his 30-year career as one of Hollywood's hottest producers, 
      Jerry Bruckheimer’s films have taken in over $14 billion dollars. Not bad 
      for a guy who started off as a commercial producer. His latest blockbuster 
      is Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End, in which the gang sets 
      off on a quest to free Captain Jack Sparrow, and the romance between Will 
      and Elizabeth heats up. Producer extraordinaire Jerry Bruckheimer will 
      join us Wednesday morning with all the details of the latest Pirates 
      flick. If you would like more information on any of these stories 
      or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us: 
      earlyshow@cbs.com
